title: Building a Compact Sim Racing Rig at Home – With a BMW Twist

author: Horatiu Boeriu
excerpt: Discover how we built a compact sim racing rig featuring the Playseat Trophy, Fanatec Podium BMW M4 GT3 wheel, and Clubsport DD wheelbase
text: For over a decade, sim racing has been on my radar, but it truly took hold during December 2019 when I attended a BMW eSports event at BMW Welt in Munich. That was the moment the racing bug bit me deeply, and ever since, I’ve been yearning for my own sim racing rig.Why I Finally Built a Sim Racing Rig at HomeThe “why” behind this dream depends entirely on who’s listening. If my wife is around, my explanation shifts toward parenting: sim racing is a great way to introduce our kids to driving and racing, steering them away from endless hours on iPads and smartphones. Admittedly, replacing screen time with another type of screen time may not be ideal, but it was the best rationale I could come up with. After all, she often reminds me that space is tight, and I certainly don’t need another hobby.But if we’re being candid, my own reasons are a bit more personal and practical. First, as an automotive journalist, track time is precious and limited. During a recent BMW M event at Abu Dhabi’s F1 track, I barely had time to learn the circuit. A home sim rig lets me practice tracks extensively beforehand, significantly enhancing my real-world driving performance. Additionally, after conversations with professional sim racers, I’ve learned just how realistic modern simulators have become, genuinely helping to improve real-world driving skills.Oh, and did I mention it’s fun? (Just don’t tell my wife I said that.) Having a dedicated sim rig in your own “man cave” is a dream shared by countless automotive enthusiasts, myself included.Choosing the Right Sim Rig: Compact Without CompromiseThe challenge, however, was balancing performance with practicality. After extensive research, including looking into full aluminum 8020 setups, I settled on the Playseat Trophy. Compact yet robust enough to handle a powerful direct drive wheelbase, it was the ideal compromise to keep both performance high and domestic harmony intact. A friend, Nate, chose the Playseat Challenge X, a foldable option, providing us with an excellent basis for comparison in the future.Playseat Trophy is feather‑light (~16 kg), compact (138 × 58 × 101 cm), yet sturdy enough for 12 Nm direct‑drive—and it can be tucked away or moved with ease, confirming your setup’s practicality.The Fanatec Setup – A BMW-Inspired Sim Racing ExperienceSelecting the wheelbase and steering wheel was equally crucial. I’ve always admired Fanatec, especially since first encountering their equipment through BMW Motorsport events. The Fanatec Podium BMW M4 GT3 wheel caught my eye years ago when BMW integrated it directly into their real-world GT3 race cars, allowing racers to literally carry their sim wheel to actual races. It felt natural to choose the same steering wheel, coupled with the Fanatec Clubsport DD wheelbase. The latter delivers a genuine and stable 12 Nm of torque, quick response (high slew rate), and reliable cooling—all engineered to maintain performance over long driving stints.The Fanatec Podium BMW M4 GT3 wheel offers racecar-grade carbon build, multiple buttons and encoders, and magnetic paddles—bringing authenticity and pro‑level control to your man‑cave cockpit.To round off the package, I added Fanatec’s CSL Pedals and the CSL Load Cell Kit. Precise braking is critical in sim racing, and these pedals offer nuanced feedback, enhancing control and realism. While there may be more advanced options available, this setup perfectly aligns with my current skills and connects directly to BMW’s own motorsport initiatives. Altogether, this rig comes in just under $3,000—definitely a serious investment, but certainly not at the highest end of the sim racing spectrum.Cost Breakdown – What This Sim Racing Rig Really CostsPlayseat Trophy: $599.00Fanatec Clubsport DD Wheelbase: $999.99Fanatec Podium BMW M4 GT3 Steering Wheel: $1,599.99Fanatec CSL Pedals: $139.99Fanatec CSL Load Cell Kit: $174.99Total Cost: Approximately $3,513.96Getting Set Up – Installation Tips and Lessons LearnedAssembling the Playseat Trophy was straightforward, taking about two hours initially, with another couple of hours fine-tuning my seating position and ergonomics. One quick tip: update the pedal firmware on your PC before installing them onto the rig. Trust me; it’ll save some frustration.The Trophy proved impressively rigid and handled the wheelbase’s power without flexing. Surprisingly, it even won approval from my wife, who now seems intrigued by this new hobby herself. As for the kids? They’re thrilled and excited about their first steps into racing.Installing the Fanatec gear was straightforward but exciting. Mounting the pedals and wheelbase required careful adjustment, but once dialed in, the experience was phenomenal. The BMW M4 GT3 steering wheel is not just beautifully designed but genuinely feels like holding a real racecar wheel—unsurprising, given it’s officially approved for global racing series.I barely scratched the surface on all the configurations and buttons on it, but if you wanna learn more about it, we shot a couple of amazing videos in the past where serious racecar drivers explained its features.Game On – My First Steps in Assetto Corsa CompetizioneI recently attended a BMW eSports bootcamp prior to the World Championship in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia—an event won by Team Redline, led by none other than Max Verstappen. Spending time with pro sim racers, I learned about setups, gear, and crucially, the best sim platforms for newcomers. While iRacing is highly recommended, I opted for Assetto Corsa Competizione (ACC) as a beginner-friendly yet realistic alternative. I’ve started with basic GT3 cars, but already I’m eyeing additional bundles and DLCs, diving deeper into sim racing acronyms and community resources.Using a PC-based setup ensures flexibility and allows room for growth. I’ve quickly become familiar with platforms and tools like Steam, Fanalab, Content Manager, Custom Shaders Patch, and various community-created tuning profiles. The goal is enjoyment and gradual skill development, not perfectionism.A Fun, Functional Rig with Room to GrowIf you’re looking to persuade your own significant other about a home sim racing setup, hopefully, this article helps. It’s compact, uses existing TV setups, and provides endless enjoyment and practical skill-building. For now, I’m embracing my beginner status but learning quickly.Stay tuned—I’ll soon share a detailed video showcasing this setup, along with regular updates on my progress and discoveries. Let the racing begin!Disclaimer: Fanatec provided the gear for review purposes with the understanding that it will be returned after testing. html:
For over a decade, sim racing has been on my radar, but it truly took hold during December 2019 when I attended a BMW eSports event at BMW Welt in Munich. That was the moment the racing bug bit me deeply, and ever since, I’ve been yearning for my own sim racing rig.

Why I Finally Built a Sim Racing Rig at Home

The “why” behind this dream depends entirely on who’s listening. If my wife is around, my explanation shifts toward parenting: sim racing is a great way to introduce our kids to driving and racing, steering them away from endless hours on iPads and smartphones. Admittedly, replacing screen time with another type of screen time may not be ideal, but it was the best rationale I could come up with. After all, she often reminds me that space is tight, and I certainly don’t need another hobby.

But if we’re being candid, my own reasons are a bit more personal and practical. First, as an automotive journalist, track time is precious and limited. During a recent BMW M event at Abu Dhabi’s F1 track, I barely had time to learn the circuit. A home sim rig lets me practice tracks extensively beforehand, significantly enhancing my real-world driving performance. Additionally, after conversations with professional sim racers, I’ve learned just how realistic modern simulators have become, genuinely helping to improve real-world driving skills.

Oh, and did I mention it’s fun? (Just don’t tell my wife I said that.) Having a dedicated sim rig in your own “man cave” is a dream shared by countless automotive enthusiasts, myself included.

Choosing the Right Sim Rig: Compact Without Compromise

The challenge, however, was balancing performance with practicality. After extensive research, including looking into full aluminum 8020 setups, I settled on the Playseat Trophy. Compact yet robust enough to handle a powerful direct drive wheelbase, it was the ideal compromise to keep both performance high and domestic harmony intact. A friend, Nate, chose the Playseat Challenge X, a foldable option, providing us with an excellent basis for comparison in the future.

Playseat Trophy is feather‑light (~16 kg), compact (138 × 58 × 101 cm), yet sturdy enough for 12 Nm direct‑drive—and it can be tucked away or moved with ease, confirming your setup’s practicality.

The Fanatec Setup – A BMW-Inspired Sim Racing Experience

Selecting the wheelbase and steering wheel was equally crucial. I’ve always admired Fanatec, especially since first encountering their equipment through BMW Motorsport events. The Fanatec Podium BMW M4 GT3 wheel caught my eye years ago when BMW integrated it directly into their real-world GT3 race cars, allowing racers to literally carry their sim wheel to actual races. It felt natural to choose the same steering wheel, coupled with the Fanatec Clubsport DD wheelbase. The latter delivers a genuine and stable 12 Nm of torque, quick response (high slew rate), and reliable cooling—all engineered to maintain performance over long driving stints.

The Fanatec Podium BMW M4 GT3 wheel offers racecar-grade carbon build, multiple buttons and encoders, and magnetic paddles—bringing authenticity and pro‑level control to your man‑cave cockpit.

To round off the package, I added Fanatec’s CSL Pedals and the CSL Load Cell Kit. Precise braking is critical in sim racing, and these pedals offer nuanced feedback, enhancing control and realism. While there may be more advanced options available, this setup perfectly aligns with my current skills and connects directly to BMW’s own motorsport initiatives. Altogether, this rig comes in just under $3,000—definitely a serious investment, but certainly not at the highest end of the sim racing spectrum.

Cost Breakdown – What This Sim Racing Rig Really Costs

  • Playseat Trophy: $599.00
  • Fanatec Clubsport DD Wheelbase: $999.99
  • Fanatec Podium BMW M4 GT3 Steering Wheel: $1,599.99
  • Fanatec CSL Pedals: $139.99
  • Fanatec CSL Load Cell Kit: $174.99

Total Cost: Approximately $3,513.96

Getting Set Up – Installation Tips and Lessons Learned

Assembling the Playseat Trophy was straightforward, taking about two hours initially, with another couple of hours fine-tuning my seating position and ergonomics. One quick tip: update the pedal firmware on your PC before installing them onto the rig. Trust me; it’ll save some frustration.

The Trophy proved impressively rigid and handled the wheelbase’s power without flexing. Surprisingly, it even won approval from my wife, who now seems intrigued by this new hobby herself. As for the kids? They’re thrilled and excited about their first steps into racing.

Installing the Fanatec gear was straightforward but exciting. Mounting the pedals and wheelbase required careful adjustment, but once dialed in, the experience was phenomenal. The BMW M4 GT3 steering wheel is not just beautifully designed but genuinely feels like holding a real racecar wheel—unsurprising, given it’s officially approved for global racing series.

I barely scratched the surface on all the configurations and buttons on it, but if you wanna learn more about it, we shot a couple of amazing videos in the past where serious racecar drivers explained its features.

Game On – My First Steps in Assetto Corsa Competizione

I recently attended a BMW eSports bootcamp prior to the World Championship in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia—an event won by Team Redline, led by none other than Max Verstappen. Spending time with pro sim racers, I learned about setups, gear, and crucially, the best sim platforms for newcomers. While iRacing is highly recommended, I opted for Assetto Corsa Competizione (ACC) as a beginner-friendly yet realistic alternative. I’ve started with basic GT3 cars, but already I’m eyeing additional bundles and DLCs, diving deeper into sim racing acronyms and community resources.

Using a PC-based setup ensures flexibility and allows room for growth. I’ve quickly become familiar with platforms and tools like Steam, Fanalab, Content Manager, Custom Shaders Patch, and various community-created tuning profiles. The goal is enjoyment and gradual skill development, not perfectionism.

A Fun, Functional Rig with Room to Grow

If you’re looking to persuade your own significant other about a home sim racing setup, hopefully, this article helps. It’s compact, uses existing TV setups, and provides endless enjoyment and practical skill-building. For now, I’m embracing my beginner status but learning quickly.

Stay tuned—I’ll soon share a detailed video showcasing this setup, along with regular updates on my progress and discoveries. Let the racing begin!

Disclaimer: Fanatec provided the gear for review purposes with the understanding that it will be returned after testing. Playseat supplied the Trophy seat for review, and it does not need to be returned.
